title: Effect of AMP on Crab Metabolism

content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The red king crab, Paralithodes camtschaticus, inhabits shallow coastal waters in the northern Pacific Ocean that can vary in temperature from <math alttext="1 degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="13 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>13</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The body temperature of the crab is typically similar to that of the surrounding water. In order to study the effect of temperature on crab metabolism, scientists purified the enzyme phosphofructokinase (<math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) from red king crabs. <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> catalyzes a reaction early in the glycolysis pathway (Figure 1). Figure 1. The conversion of fructose <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate (<math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) to fructose <math alttext="1, 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1,6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>bisphosphate (<math alttext="F B P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FBP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> The scientists determined the rate of the <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-catalyzed reaction using a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and increasing concentrations of the substrate <math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. To determine whether the reaction rate is affected by the nucleotide <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the analyses were additionally performed in the presence of <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2). Figure 2. Effect of temperature and <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> In a second analysis of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity at different temperatures, the scientists determined how the concentration of citric acid in the reaction mixture affects the rate of the reaction at <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3) in the presence of a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Citric acid is the first metabolic intermediate produced by the Krebs cycle. All reactions were performed in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 3. Effect of citric acid on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. All reactions were carried out in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Describe the role of <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the reaction shown in Figure 1.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The red king crab, Paralithodes camtschaticus, inhabits shallow coastal waters in the northern Pacific Ocean that can vary in temperature from <math alttext="1 degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="13 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>13</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The body temperature of the crab is typically similar to that of the surrounding water. In order to study the effect of temperature on crab metabolism, scientists purified the enzyme phosphofructokinase (<math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) from red king crabs. <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> catalyzes a reaction early in the glycolysis pathway (Figure 1). Figure 1. The conversion of fructose <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate (<math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) to fructose <math alttext="1, 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1,6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>bisphosphate (<math alttext="F B P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FBP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> The scientists determined the rate of the <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-catalyzed reaction using a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and increasing concentrations of the substrate <math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. To determine whether the reaction rate is affected by the nucleotide <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the analyses were additionally performed in the presence of <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2). Figure 2. Effect of temperature and <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> In a second analysis of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity at different temperatures, the scientists determined how the concentration of citric acid in the reaction mixture affects the rate of the reaction at <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3) in the presence of a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Citric acid is the first metabolic intermediate produced by the Krebs cycle. All reactions were performed in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 3. Effect of citric acid on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. All reactions were carried out in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Describe the role of <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the reaction shown in Figure 1.

(b) Identify an independent variable in the experiment shown in Figure 2. Justify the use of increasing concentrations of the substrate <math alttext="F 6 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when the scientists performed the experiments shown in Figure 2. Based on Figure 2, describe the effect of adding <math alttext="A M P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to the reactions carried out at <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on Figure 3, calculate the fold increase in the reaction rate (how many times greater the reaction rate is) between the rate at <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the presence of <math alttext="2 millimolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2 mM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> citric acid.

(c) State the alternative hypothesis for the experiments shown in Figure 3. The scientists claim that, in the absence of <math alttext="A M P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="P F K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of red king crabs functions efficiently at the crabs' typical low environmental temperatures because the active site of the enzyme can bind substrate more tightly at the low temperatures than it does at higher temperatures. Support the scientists' claim based on the data provided. Predict the effect on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the experiment shown in Figure 2 if increasing concentrations of <math alttext="F B P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FBP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are added to the reaction.

(d) When crustaceans such as crabs are kept in seawater with a lower-than-normal <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-requiring pumps that maintain ion gradients in the animals' bodies significantly increase their activity in comparison with normal levels. Explain how the increased use of <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by these pumps will most likely affect the ability of the animals to carry out other metabolic reactions such as that catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Hemolymph is the fluid in the red king crab's body that surrounds its cells and is typically slightly hypertonic to the seawater in which the crabs live. When adult crabs were removed from their native environment and placed into seawater solutions with gradually decreasing salt concentrations, their body weight increased. Explain how the crabs gained weight during this procedure.
